awd_titl_txt: Mid-Scale RI-1 (M1:DP): Compact X-ray Free-Electron Laser Project (CXFEL)
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Arizona State University to conduct a comprehensive design study of a Compact X-ray Free Electron Laser (CXFEL), a novel instrument to produce very brief and intense hard x-ray pulses at a much lower cost and smaller size than existing large-scale X-ray lasers. The smaller size and lower cost of the CXFEL will enable installation at university campuses, medical institutions, and industrial labs, greatly expanding national access and fulfilling an urgent need in the broad US research community. This instrument will directly observe, manipulate, and control molecules and materials at the nanometer spatial scale and femtosecond time scale which controls much of biochemistry and solid-state physics. Fifty investigators across a diverse range of science and engineering fields will contribute to this project, which addresses the NSF's Big Ideas for Understanding the Rules of Life, the Quantum Leap, and Growing Convergence Research. This project will build the STEM workforce through workshops and lab tours connected to Arizona State University programs that reach more than one hundred underrepresented or first-generation college students annually. Ten students will participate in undergraduate internships for each year of the project. Additionally, CXFEL will engage four local high school and community college educators each year in a five-week summer program, in which the teachers will participate in research and develop lesson plans.

The CXFEL is a room-sized X-ray laser with full coherence in time and space that allows, for the first time, full control of the frequency and temporal properties of an X-ray laser. The CXFEL offers full control of the X-ray phase using a new method of electron-beam patterning that provides customized time-structuring of the bream such as attosecond pulses, very narrow linewidths, or extremely precise timing among multiple pulses of different wavelengths. This method will be far more stable in pointing, energy, wavelength, and bandwidth than large machines. The CXFEL will be combined with related instruments into a midscale suite of probes and end-stations with highly synchronized ultrafast pulses of electrons, x-rays, and other coherent photons from terahertz to ultraviolet. The unique probe capabilities extend beyond time and space to measure momentum and energy transfer, providing the deep multidimensional information needed for transformative discoveries in a wide range of disciplines including biology, chemistry, and condensed matter physics. The primary result of the design study will be a Final Design Report including the documents needed for construction of the suite of instruments and end-stations for experiments in biochemistry, molecular dynamics, and quantum materials.  This project is supported by the Foundation-wide Mid-scale Research Infrastructure program.  The project will be managed by the Division of Biological Infrastructure with the Director for Biological Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Compact X-ray Free-Electron Laser Project (CXFEL) has completed its design phase in pursuit of studies in ultrafast time-resolved science. The CXFEL will be a novel instrument to produce sub-femtosecond coherent X-rays at reduced electron beam energy and at much lower cost than today's large $billion-scale XFELs, of which there are only a few in the world (one in the US). The CXFEL suite of ultrafast photon beams and endstations will probe the dynamics of intricate and diverse processes such as production of oxygen in the atmosphere, photosynthesis in plants, and damage and repair of DNA. It can measure the structure of oil and gas bearing rocks leading to more efficient energy production, and track catalytic reactions that are so important to industrial processes. This unique set of probes will also measure the subtle physics of quantum materials, that is, materials that exhibit exotic macroscopic properties that confound our expectations, and that may lead to breakthrough technologies, such as novel superconductors that would revolutionize energy production and storage, or quantum computers that solve problems many times faster than today's best supercomputers. These probes cover time resolution from seconds to attoseconds, the fastest scale at which dynamics occur in biochemical reactions, and spatial resolution from macroscopic to atomic scale, resolving the transfer of charge and energy at the molecular level. The unique probe capabilities of CXFEL extend beyond time and space to measure momentum and energy transfer, providing deep multidimensional information needed for transformative discoveries in a wide range of disciplines encompassing biology, chemistry, and condensed matter physics.

CXFEL builds on the latest advances in laser technology and electron beam physics to produce a room-sized X-ray laser (1/100th the size of current X-ray lasers) with full coherence in time and space, at sufficiently low cost for university campuses. It uniquely offers full control of the X-ray phase using a new method of electron-beam patterning that allows customized time-structure of the beam, e.g., attosecond pulses, very narrow linewidths, and extremely precise timing among multiple pulses with different colors. For the first time, we will have full control of the frequency and temporal properties of an X-ray laser. The method will be far more stable in pointing, energy, wavelength, and bandwidth than large machines. We integrate the hardware with sophisticated machine learning software to create highly flexible and efficient ultrafast science instruments. The resulting probes include attosecond pulses of soft X-rays from CXFEL, femtosecond pulses of hard X-rays from the newly commissioning Compact X-ray Light Source (CXLS), single-cycle terahertz generation for strong excitation fields, and tightly synchronized tunable laser pulses from mid-infrared to the UV. The primary outcome of this project is construction-ready design of the CXFEL instruments and endstations, including algorithms and experimental capabilities in biochemistry, atomic, molecular and optical (AMO) science, and quantum materials.
